title: How to Install Windows XP on Ubuntu with VirtualBox

steps.title: Install
steps.content: Install Oracle VM VirtualBox. VirtualBox acts as a "computer" on which to host operating systems.

steps.title: Extract an ISO image from a Windows XP CD you have, IMGburn and k3b have this functionality.
steps.content: Extract an ISO image from a Windows XP CD you have, IMGburn and k3b have this functionality.

steps.title: Click
steps.content: Click the "New" button (the first of the four below the menu).

steps.title: Use the Wizard
steps.content: Use the Wizard to create a virtual partition for Windows XP. Windows XP is the default OS selected, so all you have to do is name it. (Windows XP, for example, is a good name).

steps.title: Choose
steps.content: Choose the amount of RAM to be allocated to this OS (when it's in use). Don't allocate too much because there will be less RAM for your host system to run, which will crash your entire system.

steps.title: Create
steps.content: Create a new hard disk since you probably don't have one already. Click Next to Continue. You will be taken through the Create New Virtual Disk wizard, which will allow you to choose hard disk size, dynamically expanding/fixed size, etc.

steps.title: Review
steps.content: Review the summary it provides at the end and verify the information is correct. After that, the new Virtual Machine will be created.

steps.title: Mount
steps.content: Mount the ISO image by clicking on the Settings button. Click the Storage section on the left hand side of the window. Click on the Empty CD medium in the Storage Tree.

steps.title: Open
steps.content: Open the Virtual Media Manager, depicted with an icon like a folder with an up arrow, next to CD/DVD Device under "Attributes".

steps.title: Add
steps.content: Add the disk image file by clicking Add, then choosing the location of the Windows XP ISO image. Select it with "Select", then press OK in the Settings Window. Launch the VirtualBox by pressing "Start".

steps.title: Install
steps.content: Install Windows. You should have the Windows installer running now. Remember that since you have not yet install the Guest Additions, you will have to press your Host key (normally Right-Ctrl)

steps.title: Install
steps.content: Install Guest Additions. While the machine is running, under the "Devices" menu, click "Install Guest Additions", which will launch a setup wizard inside Windows XP. Now you will have OS mouse integration, so you won't have to press the host key to switch between your host and guest. You also can copy and paste between the two operating systems. Now that you have Windows XP installed, you can install programs you use.
